channel.title: Latest alerts from washingtonpost.com
channel.description: An unofficial feed created by Derek Willis.

item.title: Trump’s speech. Republican split. Liverpool car incident. Gaza school. Cancer risk. Hot weather. Mysterious bucket. Catch up now.
item.description: Catch up in minutes with these 7 stories.

item.title: 81 years after he died in World War II, a young aviator was buried in his California hometown
item.description: Second Lt. Thomas V. Kelly Jr. was 21 when he perished with 10 other men on a B-24 bomber shot down near New Guinea on March 11, 1944. Two years ago, his remains and those of three other crew members were recovered from the underwater crash site. Kelly was buried Monday beside family members in Livermore, California.

item.title: How well do you understand your dog’s emotions? Here’s what research tells us.
item.description: Dog owners don’t understand their pet’s emotions as well as they think they do.

item.title: Charles Rangel dies at 94. He was the first African American chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee.
item.description: The New York Democrat was a powerful voice for Harlem in Congress but was forced to relinquish his chairmanship because of a series of financial transgressions.

item.title: Carolyn Hax: Stepparent resents husband’s ex over teen’s support agreement
item.description: Carolyn Hax: Stepparent resents husband’s ex over teen’s support agreement

item.title: See what happened when these Post readers stopped mowing their lawns
item.description: Whether you have a small yard or acres to spare, these reader-submitted photos show that retiring your lawn mower can mean less work, more wildlife and a display of blooms.

item.title: Six veterans reflect on Memorial Day — and 364 other days we should not forget
item.description: How to honor Memorial Day? Reach out to veterans’ families. Honor the Constitution. Remember the privilege as well as the sacrifice.

item.title: Happy long weekend! Play today’s On the Record now.
item.description: Answer now to earn your Memorial Day points.

item.title: Trump scolds Putin. Tariff delay. Elon Musk’s future. Firebomb plot. Credit scores. Vaccine rules. Beauty ratings. Catch up now.
item.description: Catch up in minutes with these 7 stories.

item.title: It’s been five years since George Floyd’s murder. Much of the promised ‘racial reckoning’ never emerged.
item.description: His murder by Minneapolis police in 2020 set off a summer of protests and promises to address the country’s racial inequality. Five years later, many of those efforts have either been reversed or never materialized.

item.title: This teen lost her mother and sister in the DCA crash. They’d wanted her to win an upcoming piano competition. And so she played.
item.description: For Anne Valerie Ter, the piano was an extension of herself, from the time she first laid eyes on the instrument as a 1-year-old. After the death of her mother and sister, she pounded her grief into the piano keys as she faced Rachmaninoff’s daunting Piano Concerto No. 2.

item.title: Still need to finish this weekend’s On the Record? We’ve got you.
item.description: Play now to finish out your score for the week.

item.title: Where do you stand on this fierce generational divide? Swipe through our test to find out.
item.description: A breakdown of why young people insist on recording videos vertically — and why older folks hate it.

item.title: Crossword and a coffee: Solve the Sunday puzzle now
item.description: Crossword and a coffee: Solve the Sunday puzzle now

item.title: This scientist spent years studying ‘super agers.’ Here’s the lifestyle change he focuses on most.
item.description: Cardiologist Eric Topol, 70, previously emphasized aerobic exercise. His research led him to significant changes in his routine.

item.title: A Kansas family farm, barely getting by, grapples with Trump’s cuts
item.description: Farmer Jacob Thomas was “barely making it” before the federal cuts this year. Then he and his wife lost 10 percent of their business when the Agriculture Department cut a billion dollars from funding to grow local food for schools and food banks. Other grants they hoped to use to expand are up in the air or have evaporated. “For the first time in my life,” Thomas said, “I don’t trust the government is going to follow through on their word.”

item.title: How many guesses will Keyword take you today? Try to beat the average now.
item.description: How many guesses will Keyword take you today? Try to beat the average now.

item.title: Immigrant arrests at courthouses signal new tactic in Trump’s deportation push
item.description: U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement officers have been instructed to arrest people immediately after a judge has ordered them to be deported or after prosecutors move to drop their cases. The coordinated operation is the government’s latest attempt to quickly remove people from the country — even if officials have to bypass the courts — as concern grows in the White House that President Donald Trump won’t be able to fulfill his campaign promise to remove millions of undocumented immigrants from the United States.

item.title: White House abruptly dismisses NSC staffers in significant reorganization
item.description: The dismissals, part of a plan to downsize the coordinating body, follow President Donald Trump’s recent ouster of his national security adviser.

item.title: Judge strikes down Trump's executive order targeting Jenner & Block law firm
item.description: It is the second time a federal judge has ruled that President Donald Trump's unprecedented actions to punish a law firm are unconstitutional.

item.title: Judge temporarily blocks Trump administration’s effort to ban Harvard University from enrolling international students
item.description: A federal judge in Massachusetts granted Harvard an order on Friday that prevents the Department of Homeland Security from revoking the school’s certification to enroll international students. The decision comes one day after DHS told the school that foreign students must transfer from the university or risk losing their visa status.

item.title: Body slamming? Officer aggression? The clash with ICE that led to charges against a Democratic congresswoman.
item.description: The Washington Post analyzed hours of witness video to assess conflicting accounts of a tussle this month involving Rep. LaMonica McIver (D-New Jersey) and Immigration and Customs Enforcement at a Newark detention center.

item.title: 10 questions, plus a bonus wager! It’s the weekend edition of On the Record.
item.description: Think you’ve got what it takes to earn a perfect score? Take today’s longer news quiz and complete your point total for the week.

item.title: Trump proposes 50 percent tariff on European Union, takes aim at Apple
item.description:
President Donald Trump proposed a 50 percent tariff on all goods from the European Union, declaring that trade negotiations with the E.U. were “going nowhere.”
In a separate media post, Trump threatened Apple with a minimum 25 percent tariff if the tech giant did not make iPhones for American customers in the United States.

item.title: Harvard suing Trump administration over the abrupt revocation of its ability to enroll international students
item.description: The university said it was filing a lawsuit Friday morning against the administration, challenging its decision Thursday to block the school’s certification to admit foreign students.

item.title: Trump vs. Harvard. Budget bill. Crypto dinner. D.C. shooting. Supreme Court. Vitamin D. Bear cub. Catch up now.
item.description: Catch up in minutes with these 7 stories.

item.title: Supreme Court allows Trump to fire independent regulators for now, casting doubt on 90-year-old legal precedent
item.description: The order, which drew a sharp dissent from the three liberal justices, powerfully endorsed President Donald Trump’s authority over the federal bureaucracy. But the court said it would not impact the independence of the Federal Reserve.

item.title: FBI says suspect in D.C. Jewish Museum shooting confessed to killings
item.description: Elias Rodriguez, 31, faces murder and firearms charges in the killings of two Israeli Embassy workers. The charges could carry the death penalty, but interim U.S. attorney Jeanine Pirro said it's too soon to decide whether to pursue capital punishment.

item.title: Trump administration revokes Harvard’s ability to enroll foreign students
item.description: In a letter, Homeland Security Secretary Kristi Noem said her agency had revoked Harvard’s Student and Exchange Visitor Program certification. The move means the university may no longer enroll foreign students, and existing foreign students must transfer or risk losing their legal status, DHS said, adding that Harvard had created an "unsafe campus” by allowing anti-American agitators, many of them foreign students.

item.title: Carolyn Hax: Husband brushes off his side texts to a female co-worker
item.description: Carolyn Hax: Husband brushes off his side texts to a female co-worker

item.title: Senate votes to block California’s EV rule, sending measure to Trump. The move could affect car sales in a dozen states.
item.description: The Senate voted to block California from enforcing a rule that would ban sales of new gasoline-powered cars in the state by 2035. The vote marks the GOP’s latest effort to curtail state-level efforts to tackle climate change, even as President Donald Trump and congressional leaders have empowered states to set their own education policies and abortion laws.

item.title: Judge blocks layoffs at Education Department, stalling Trump’s effort to close the agency
item.description: A federal judge in Boston directed President Donald Trump’s administration to reinstate federal employees who were terminated so the department can continue to carry out its statutory functions.

item.title: Former British prime minister Liz Truss: ‘Elites killed my pro-growth agenda. Trump can’t let them stop his.’
item.description: The White House’s proposed tax cuts, tariffs and spending reforms are showing the West the way forward.

item.title: Supreme Court deadlocks, blocking creation of nation’s first public religious charter school
item.description: With only eight justices voting, the Supreme Court’s 4-4 tie leaves in place an Oklahoma state Supreme Court decision that blocked the creation of the Catholic school and said it would be unconstitutional. A ruling for St. Isidore of Seville Catholic Virtual School would have for the first time allowed direct and complete taxpayer funding to establish a faith-based school, allowing government sponsorship of a curriculum that calls for students to adhere to Catholic beliefs and the church’s religious mission.

item.title: Supreme Court upholds fraud conviction of government contractor
item.description: The case involved Alpha Painting & Construction and a project manager, Stamatios Kousisis, who was sentenced to 70 months in prison for obtaining a multimillion-dollar contract under false pretenses.

item.title: Dale Earnhardt Sr. was 49 when he died. As his son neared that age, he went looking for answers.
item.description: Reporter Kent Babb, whose dad died at 51, always dreaded turning that age. Babb wondered how Dale Earnhardt Jr., the iconic NASCAR driver, was coping as he approached 49. “God, I wish he was here for me,” Junior told Babb.

item.title: A night to remember for this actor in today’s On the Record
item.description: Answer now to earn your Thursday points.

item.title: D.C. shooting. Oval Office confrontation. Budget bill. Deportation flight. Lonely men. Nor’easter. Lincoln’s gloves. Catch up now.
item.description: Catch up in minutes with these 7 stories.

item.title: House narrowly passes Trump’s sweeping tax and immigration bill, sending the measure to the Senate
item.description: The bill would extend tax cuts from 2017 that are otherwise set to expire, create some new tax breaks, and spend billions on deportations and defense. Congress’s nonpartisan bookkeeper says it would add $2.3 trillion to the national debt over 10 years.

item.title: Two Israeli Embassy staff killed near Capital Jewish Museum in D.C.
item.description: The two diplomatic staff were shot late Wednesday, Homeland Security Secretary Kristi L. Noem said.

item.title: Oklahoma City Thunder guard Shai Gilgeous-Alexander wins his first NBA MVP award
item.description: Gilgeous-Alexander led the NBA in scoring and guided the Thunder to a league-best 68-14 record in the regular season. He is the third Oklahoma City player to win the league’s top individual award, joining Kevin Durant and Russell Westbrook, and the second Canadian-born player, joining Steve Nash.

item.title: Judge blasts prosecutors for ‘embarrassing retraction of charges’ against Newark Mayor Ras Baraka
item.description: The Justice Department dropped trespassing charges against Baraka after a clash outside an ICE detention facility. Rep. LaMonica McIver (D) faces two charges of assaulting a law enforcement officer.

item.title: Federal judge says Trump’s decision to remove several immigrants to South Sudan violates his previous court order
item.description: U.S. District Judge Brian E. Murphy said the Trump administration “obviously” violated his previous order to give immigrants a meaningful opportunity to challenge their removal to a country where they are not citizens. He said the government notified the immigrants the day before they were deported.

item.title: Trump confronts South African president over violence against White farmers in extraordinary Oval Office meeting
item.description: President Donald Trump made no mention of the nation’s long-standing epidemic of violence against both White and Black people, nor its violent and discriminatory history of White rule. South African President Cyril Ramaphosa acknowledged a violence epidemic in his nation but denied a “genocide,” as Trump claimed, and said it was an issue of “criminality.”

item.title: Pentagon takes possession of Qatari luxury jet sought by Trump for use as Air Force One
item.description: President Donald Trump has praised Qatar for offering the $400 million plane to his administration, but a raft of national security experts have panned the idea, saying it raises significant cost and security concerns, while members of Congress have questioned whether the deal is ethical.

item.title: Florida prosecutors investigate nonprofit linked to initiative led by Casey DeSantis and championed by husband Gov. Ron DeSantis
item.description: Hope Florida Foundation has been mired in controversy since state Republicans began examining why the nonprofit received a $10 million payment from a Medicaid settlement.

item.title: Carolyn Hax: Fiancé wants her parents, who don’t work, to pay for their wedding
item.description: Carolyn Hax: Fiancé wants her parents, who don’t work, to pay for their wedding

item.title: Dining chat: Tom Sietsema’s take on a critic nearly getting booted from the French Laundry
item.description: Dining chat: Tom Sietsema’s take on a critic nearly getting booted from the French Laundry

item.title: Justice Dept. abandons police accountability efforts in Louisville, Minneapolis days before 5th anniversary of George Floyd’s death
item.description: The new civil rights chief at the Justice Department said the government will drop out of reform agreements negotiated during the Biden administration, undoing a signature effort to reshape local law enforcement after high-profile killings by officers ignited widespread outrage.

item.title: Can you tell me how to get to today’s On the Record?
item.description: Answer now to earn your Wednesday points.
